properties.headline: Flood Warning issued February 6 at 9:09PM EST until February 7 at 3:00AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a

* Flood Warning for...
Central and southern Greenville County in Upstate South Carolina...

* Until 300 AM EST.

* At 901 PM EST, Greenville County Emergency Management continues
to report numerous roads still closed due to flooding, especially
along the Reedy River and associated tributaries in the city of
Greenville generally north of Westfield St.  Although flash
flooding has ended, floodwaters from the Reedy River and
associated tributaries are still very slow to recede and are
still threatening several homes and other structures in the
vicinity, including along Willard St. Additionally, the floodwave
continues to progress down the Reedy into southern Greenville
County and additional rises there are expected into the overnight
hours.  Therefore, though the flash flood threat has ended for
this event, a Flood Warning has been issued to continue to
highlight numerous ongoing flooding impacts.

* Numerous roads will remain closed across the warned area.
DO NOT DRIVE THROUGH FLOODED ROADWAYS. Please obey all barricades.
It is extremely difficult at night to assess the depth of flooding
and roads may be damaged or washed away underneath the flood
waters.  Barricades remain in place until engineers can assess
the stability of the road or bridge and ensure its safety.

* Some locations that may continue to experience flooding include...
Greenville Downtown, Greenville Eastside, West Greenville, Mauldin,
Taylors, Simpsonville, Berea, Five Forks, Fountain Inn and Welcome.
properties.instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding in urban
areas. Storm drains, streams and other drainages will become
overwhelmed by excessive rainfall, flooding low-lying roads,
intersections, and parking lots. Underpasses are especially dangerous
because sudden flood waters can quickly surround and submerge your
vehicle. Stay alert and avoid flood-prone areas.

Numerous roads, parking lots and bridges are threatened by floodwaters.
Please pay close attention to road signs indicating a flood-prone area.
Obey all barricades, even if water is not currently over the road.
Barricades are in place for your protection and indicate areas where
flooding can occur rapidly and without warning.
